Award.AwardTitle: III Nitride NEMS Devices for Chemical and Biological Sensing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
0928888
Wu Lu
Ohio State University

This project aims to develop GaN nanoelectromechanical system (NEMS) biosensors utilizing the excitation of nanoscale beam mechanical resonators modulated by the mass or surface energy change of specific binging between receptors and target analytes. The NEMS biosensors will be integrated with an on-chip low noise amplifier for signal amplification on a microfluidic platform. To improve the device sensitivity, piezoelectric materials, namely, AlGaN/GaN heterostructures will be used for freely suspended beam resonators and vertical beam resonators. The proposed NEMS devices promise to be extremely fast and ultrahigh sensitive devices for sensor applications such as displacement and charge detection due to specific analyte binding. The ultra-sensitive NEMS sensors can find various applications from food safety, homeland security to disease diagnostics for human health care. Special efforts will be made to recruit female and underrepresented minority graduate and undergraduate students for participation of this interdisciplinary research. Outreach activities include school visits, summer camp and training of high school senior students.

Institution.Name: Ohio State University Research Foundation -DO NOT USE
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: OHIO STATE UNIVERSITY RESEARCH FOUNDATION, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: Ohio State University Research Foundation -DO NOT USE

ProgramReference.Text: SENSORS AND SENSOR SYSTEMS FOR CIS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project is to develop III-nitride nanoelectromechanical systems (NEMS) and to develop an ultrahigh sensitive biosensor based on such NEMS devices for detection of chemical agents and bio-molecules such as DNAs, proteins, and viruses. Toward this goal, we have designed the device structures and developed processes for fabrication of GaN based lateral and vertical beam resonators. The major research activities include: (1) design of vertical beam NEMS devices with GHz resonant frequency; (2) process development of vertical beam GaN resonator devices; (3) process development of GaN cantilevers by photoelectrochemical (PEC) etching including bandgap selective and dopant selective PEC etching processes; (4) process development of GaN cantilevers by dry etching; (5) measurement and characterization of GaN NEMS devices. Through these activities, we have successfully fabricated III-nitride semiconductor vertical beam resonators and lateral beam arrays as well as clamp resonators. We also developed low cost characterization techniques with sub-nanometer resolution. The findings and results from this research project will have direct impact on both research community and society toward the evolution of semiconductor device technology (sensors) and MEMS/NEMS devices in many defense, national security, and commercial applications. Three Ph.D students directly or indirectly support under this project have graduated and received their Ph.D degrees. Three undergraduate student researchers supported by REU supplements are currently graduate students at OSU and University of California at Berkeley. Other outreach and educational activities including nanobiotechnology lab demonstration and tour to local high school students and Engineering Freshmen at College of Engineering OSU, as well as hosting high school seniors for research internships.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The objective of this project is to develop III-nitride nanoelectromechanical systems (NEMS) and to develop an ultrahigh sensitive biosensor based on such NEMS devices for detection of chemical agents and bio-molecules such as DNAs, proteins, and viruses. Toward this goal, we have designed the device structures and developed processes for fabrication of GaN based lateral and vertical beam resonators. The major research activities include: (1) design of vertical beam NEMS devices with GHz resonant frequency; (2) process development of vertical beam GaN resonator devices; (3) process development of GaN cantilevers by photoelectrochemical (PEC) etching including bandgap selective and dopant selective PEC etching processes; (4) process development of GaN cantilevers by dry etching; (5) measurement and characterization of GaN NEMS devices. Through these activities, we have successfully fabricated III-nitride semiconductor vertical beam resonators and lateral beam arrays as well as clamp resonators. We also developed low cost characterization techniques with sub-nanometer resolution. The findings and results from this research project will have direct impact on both research community and society toward the evolution of semiconductor device technology (sensors) and MEMS/NEMS devices in many defense, national security, and commercial applications. Three Ph.D students directly or indirectly support under this project have graduated and received their Ph.D degrees. Three undergraduate student researchers supported by REU supplements are currently graduate students at OSU and University of California at Berkeley. Other outreach and educational activities including nanobiotechnology lab demonstration and tour to local high school students and Engineering Freshmen at College of Engineering OSU, as well as hosting high school seniors for research internships.
